Trifluoromethylation is an important route to achieve the organic fluorinated compounds. In the present work, heterogeneous catalyst of MgSO4/ZrO2 with Lewis base and acid was designed and prepared for the heterogeneous catalytic trifluoromethylation of aldehydes with (trifluoromethyl)trimethylsilane to the α-(trifluoromethyl)benzyl alcohol. The prepared catalyst was characterized to reveal its structure by XRD, FT-IR, Py-FTIR, Raman, XPS, NH3-TPD, CO2-TPD, and TGA. The heterogenous catalyst showed good catalytic performances with 99 % yield of α-(trifluoromethyl) benzyl alcohol at room temperature. The active sites on the surface of MgSO4/ZrO2 were investigated by the adsorption/reaction heat with the microcalorimeter. The reaction mechanism was proposed. The heterogenous catalyst possessed good stability for the entitled reaction. In addition, it showed good universality for the trifluoromethylation of various benzaldehyde derivatives to the corresponding α-(trifluoromethyl) benzyl alcohol. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Trifluoromethylation Α-(trifluoromethyl)benzyl alcohol (trifluoromethyl)trimethylsilane Acidic sites Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Organic fluorinated compounds are widely applied in the fields of pharmaceuticals, agrochemicals and biotechnology due to its lipophilicity, membrane permeability, electronegativity, and antioxidant properties [1,2]. Especially, the trifluoromethylated compound, as one of the most vital fluorinated compounds, attracts increasing interesting in medicine discovery and agricultural chemicals synthesis [3,4]. (Trifluoromethyl)trimethylsilane (TMSCF3), known as the Ruppert's reagent, acts as one of the most promising and convenient trifluoromethylation agents to introduce the trifluoromethyl directly to the substrate of carbonyl compounds such as aldehyde, ketone, and ester [3,5]. The Si-CF3 bond in the TMSCF3 can be easily broken because of the strong electron-withdrawing nature of the CF3 group. In this way, TMSCF3 is usually activated by a nucleophile addition, such as halide ion, acetate, alkoxide, and carbonate [6–12] to release the CF3 − attacking the electrophilic carbon. With the typical reaction between aldehyde and TMSCF3 as the example, there are few examples of other catalysts [3], especially the heterogeneous catalyst, for the effective catalytic enhancement. Trifluoromethylation from TMSCF3 can also be catalyzed by Lewis base or Lewis acid to avoid the consumption of strong base of fluoride and alkoxide. Lewis bases, such as dibutylamine, PPh3, LiOAc, triethylamine N-oxide, and N-heterocyclic carbene, have been reported to catalyse CF3 − addition [7,13–15]. However, a problem suffered is that amount of active CF3 − is lost, which inhibits its entrance in the catalytic cycle [16]. Lewis acid species can protect the rapidly generated CF3 − anion to release it slowly. Lewis acid such as trialkyl borates and Ti(O i Pr)4 has been reported to temporary trap the CF3 − anion produced by KF from TMSCF3 [16,17]. Therefore, it is expected to explore the catalytic system with Lewis base-acid sites to control the release rate and stability of CF3 − anion during the reaction process. In the present work, MgSO4 supported on ZrO2 as the catalyst with both Lewis base and acid was prepared. It is expected that oxygen atoms from the sulfate act the Lewis base site while the Zr atoms form ZrO2 provide the Lewis acid sites. The present catalytic system shows the excellent catalytic performances for trifluoromethylation of benzyl aldehyde with TMSCF3 as trifluoromethylation agents in N, N-dimethylformamide (DMF) solvent. The prepared catalyst was characterized and the reaction heat of the titled reaction was measured. The reaction mechanism was proposed. The present catalyst showed good stability and universality for benzyl aldehyde derivates. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials All other chemicals are of analytical grade and do not require further purification for use. 2.2 Preparation of catalysts A 0.24 g of MgSO4 and 1.23 g of ZrO2 were mixed and ground into a fine powder with a ball milling tank. After the end of ball milling, it was put into a muffle furnace and heated to 600 °C at a rate of 5 °C/min for 3 h. The calcined catalyst was collected and named as MgSO4/ZrO2. The loading of MgSO4 in MgSO4/ZrO2 was 16.3 wt%. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The X-ray diffraction was carried out on the Rigaku D/max 2500. Scanning electron microscope for the morphology of the sample was tested on the Hitachi S-4800. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy was performed on a Thermo Fisher's ESCALAB 250Xi electronic spectrometer. All binding energies were corrected based on the C1s peak at 284.8 eV. The Raman spectra were obtained on a Laser microscopic Raman imaging spectrometer (Thermo Fisher, USA) equipped with a 532 nm Ne laser. The N2 adsorption/desorption tests were carried out on a Micromeritics ASAP 2460. Programmed temperature chemisorption (NH3/CO2-TPD) characterization was performed on an AutoChem1 II 2920. Thermogravimetric analysis was carried out on HITACHI STA200 with the ramp rate was 20 °C/min under nitrogen atmosphere. Pyridine-FTIR spectroscopy (Py-FTIR) adopted a Bruker tensor 27 Fourier infrared spectrometer with the in situ cell of CaF2window, collected 32 times with a resolution of 4 cm−1. Prior to measurements, the samples were degassed at 200 °C for 12 h under vacuum. Calorimetric tests for the adsorption heat were carried out on a microcalorimeter SetaramC80 of Tian-Calvet type. The test was carried out using a membrane mixed reaction cell as previously reported [18]. Prior to the test, the liquid was put on the top of the membrane while the solid sample was loaded under the membrane in the reactor. The solid catalyst was 15.0 mg while the liquid was the DMF solution (1.0 mL) of benzaldehyde (12.8 mg) and TMSCF3 (35.5 mg). After reaching equilibrium, the liquids and solids were mixed completely at 25.00 °C and the heat flow of the reaction was recorded with the time. 2.4 Catalytic performance All reactions were carried out in 25 mL glass pressure-resistant tubes. MgSO4/ZrO2 (30 mg), benzaldehyde (0.25 mmol), TMSCF3 (0.5 mmol), and DMF (2.0 mL) were added into the above tube. The mixture was stirred vigorously at room temperature for 2 h. After reaction, the catalyst was filtered out and 1.0 mL of aqueous hydrochloric acid was added to the filtrate with vigorous stirring for 1 h. Subsequently, the reaction solution was analysed with a gas chromatograph (GC) to obtain the yield of the α-(trifluoromethyl)benzyl alcohol. The GC was equipped with a weak polarity column of HP-5 and a flame ionization detector (FID). The injection port temperature was 260 °C, and the temperature of the FID detector was 270 °C. The yield of the product was calculated by the internal standard method with naphthalene as the internal standard by Eq. (1). (1) Y i e l d = ( n f n 0 ) × 100 % where n 0 was the theoretical moles of α-(trifluoromethyl)benzyl alcohol based on the benzaldehyde, and n f was moles of produced α-(trifluoromethyl)benzyl alcohol. 2.5 Kinetic studies The reaction kinetic was investigated according to our previous method [19,20]. Typically, the reaction order was determined by the integral form of the first order reaction rate equation as shown in Eq. (2). (2) − l n ( 1 − X ) = k t where X was the conversion of substrate, k was the rate constant, and t was the reaction time. If good linearity was obtained by plotting -ln(1-X) against the reaction time t, the reaction can be determined as the first-order reaction and the rate constant k can be obtained by the slope. 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Optimization of the reaction condition The prepared catalysts are employed to examine their catalytic performances on the titled reaction. It can be found that the yield of α-(trifluoromethyl) benzyl alcohol (TFMBA) is 13 % without catalyst (Table 1 , entry 1), which is attributed to that the DMF solvent can promote nucleophilic addition to aldehydes [21,22]. With ZrO2 as the catalyst, the yield of TFMBA is the same level to that without catalyst (Table 1, entry 2), indicating that ZrO2 alone does not have the catalytic activity for the titled reaction. With MgSO4 as the catalyst, the yield can achieve 83 % (Table 1, entry 3). The yield of TFMBA reaches 84 % over physical mixture of MgSO4 and ZrO2 (Table 1, entry 4) which shows the same reactive level of MgSO4 alone, further confirming that ZrO2 has no catalysis for the titled reaction. When the MgSO4 is supported on the ZrO2, the catalytic performance can be further improved to 99 % yield of TFMBA over MgSO4/ZrO2 (Table 1, entry 5) which is better than that of physical mixture of MgSO4 and ZrO2, indicating that MgSO4 and ZrO2 interacts with each other to synergistically enhance the catalytic activity. With these results in hand, several commonly supports are employed to prepare the supported MgSO4 catalyst for their catalytic performances (Table 1, entries 5–8). Only ZrO2 and TiO2 supported MgSO4 exhibit the excellent catalytic results, which is probably attributed to that the surface sulphate can interact with adjacent Zr 4+ and Ti 4+ [23,24]. To illustrate the effect of Mg2+ cation and SO4 2− anion, the controlled experiments are carried out on Na2SO4/ZrO2 and MgCl2/ZrO2 (Table 1, entries 9 and 10). Na2SO4/ZrO2 only gives 13 % yield while MgCl2/ZrO2 has 82 % yield, implying that Mg2+ plays the main active sites and SO4 2− can synergistically enhance the activity in the MgSO4/ZrO2. With MgSO4/ZrO2 as the heterogeneous catalyst, the effect of the catalyst amount for the reaction is investigated. As shown in Fig. 1a , the reaction activity is improved with the dosage of the catalyst increasing. This is because that more active sites can be provided when increases of the loading catalyst. The TFMBA can be completely formed when the amount of catalyst is higher than 30 mg. The reaction time is also examined to obtain the optimized reaction time. As shown in Fig. 1b, the yield of TFMBA reaches 78 % at 1 h. The yield can reach 99 % when the reaction time is 2 h. The yield is not changed with reaction time further prolonging, indicating no side reaction occurs. The reaction solvent for the titled reaction is also screened with the commonly used solvents such as acetonitrile, dimethyl sulfoxide, N, N-dimethylformamide, 1,4-dioxane, ethanol, tetrahydrofuran, and water. As shown in Table 2 , there is no reaction in the solvents of 1,4-dioxane, ethanol, tetrahydrofuran, and water. N, N-dimethylformamide performances the best for the titled reaction, which is due to that the solvent can provide electrons from nitrogen to Si atom of TFMCF3 to form the activated silicon species [3,25]. It is worth noted that homogeneous catalyst or additive are often employed for the titled reaction. Typically, catalytic amount of CsF and tetrabutylammonium fluoride are employed as the fluoride initiator to form the Me3SiF and alkoxide adduct [6,26]. Some are the basic additive such as LiOAc, KOH, tetrabutylammonium acetate [14,27]. To our best knowledge, this is the first report of the heterogeneous catalyst for the trifluoromethylation of aldehyde with TMSCF3. In addition, the reaction can be scaled up with 5 and 10 times under the standard mild condition (Table 1, entries 11 and 12), giving the yield of 95 % and 93 %, respectively. This indicates that the present heterogeneous catalytic system has the greatly potential for industrial production of TFMBA from trifluoromethylation due to the merits of easy separation and scaled-up feasibility. 3.2 Characterization of the catalyst To insight into the reason for the excellent catalytic performances, the catalyst structure is investigated by various characterizations. The morphology of the series of catalysts was analyzed by SEM images (Fig. S1.), showing block structure. The prepared MgSO4/ZrO2 catalyst was characterized by XRD to determine the crystalline structure. As shown in Fig. 2 , the characteristic peaks of ZrO2 are the features of the monoclinic ZrO2. When the MgSO4 is loaded on the ZrO2, the main peaks are identical to the monoclinic ZrO2, implying that crystalline structure of ZrO2 is not changed. The peak at 25.1° in the MgSO4/ZrO2 are attributed to the MgSO4, indicating that MgSO4 has been successfully supported on the ZrO2. Besides, the thermal stability of the prepared MgSO4/ZrO2 is characterized by the TGA (Fig. S2). The weight loss below 300 °C is less than 0.5 % which is attributed to the water in the crystal structure. The thermal stability of the sample is high, which can keep stable as high as 700 °C. To further characterize the catalyst, the FT-IR and Raman techniques are employed. As shown in Fig. 3a , peaks at 3200 to 3600 cm−1 in MgSO4/ZrO2 are attributed to OH stretching modes in water adsorbed on the catalyst. The peak at 1654 cm−1 in MgSO4 is assigned to water bending mode [28], which moves to 1641 cm−1 in MgSO4/ZrO2. The peaks at 1083 and 1022 cm−1 in MgSO4 are recognized as the bonded S = O stretching vibration [29,30], which shift to 1091 and 1028 cm−1 in MgSO4/ZrO2. These shifting of peaks implies that MgSO4 interacts with ZrO2 when it is supported on the ZrO2 [31]. As shown in Fig. 3b, the typical peaks of MgSO4 and ZrO2 are observed in MgSO4/ZrO2, indicating that MgSO4 is successfully supported on ZrO2. As the reaction occurs on the surface of the heterogeneous catalyst, the surface chemical environment of the prepared MgSO4, ZrO2, and MgSO4/ZrO2 are investigated by the XPS technique. As shown in Fig. 4a , the binding energy of Zr 3d have two peaks at 184.6 eV and 182.3 eV in MgSO4/ZrO2, corresponding to the Zr 3d3/2 and Zr 3d5/2 respectively. The binding energy difference between 3d3/2 and 3d5/2 spin-orbit doublet is in line with the existence of Zr4+ species [32,33]. This binding energy of Zr 3d in MgSO4/ZrO2 is slightly higher than that of ZrO2 (184.3 eV and 182.0 eV). This indicates that the surface Zr4+ species in MgSO4/ZrO2 donates electrons compared with the Zr4+ in ZrO2, which is ascribed to the formation of a complex like interaction between Zr4+ and SO4 2−[32,34,35] For Mg 1 s (Fig. 4b), the binding energy of Mg 1 s in MgSO4/ZrO2 is located at 1304.0 eV, indicating the existence of Mg2+ species, which is slightly lower than that in bulk MgSO4 (1304.5 eV). This suggests that the surface Mg2+ species accept electrons when it is supported on ZrO2, implying that the existence of interactions between the Mg2+ species and ZrO2 [36–39]. For S 2p (Fig. 4c), the peak at 169.5 eV is observed in MgSO4/ZrO2, which is ascribed to the S6+ in SO4 2− [35,39,40]. The binding energy of S2p in MgSO4/ZrO2 is lower than that in bulk MgSO4 (170.6 eV), implying the interaction between the ZrO2 and SO4 2 from MgSO4. For the O1s (Fig. 4d), two peaks centered at 533.2 and 531.8 eV in bulk MgSO4 are attributed to the oxygen in chemisorbed water and sulfate [41], respectively. Three peaks at 533.0, 531.6, and 529.5 eV in bulk ZrO2 are observed, which are assigned to the adsorbed oxygen species, defect oxygen, and lattice oxygen [42], respectively. Three peaks of 532.8, 531.6 and 529.7 eV can be deconvoluted in MgSO4/ZrO2, corresponding to adsorbed oxygen species, defect/sulfate oxygen, and lattice oxygen. In a word, the interaction exists between the MgSO4 and ZrO2 in MgSO4/ZrO2 catalyst. In order to determine the acidic and basic properties of the prepared samples, temperature-programmed desorption of NH3 (NH3-TPD) and CO2 (CO2-TPD) are evaluated. As for the NH3-TPD curve shown in Fig. 5a , there is no peak for MgSO4 and ZrO2, indicating that there are have no acidic sites. Compared with MgSO4 and ZrO2, MgSO4/ZrO2 has a strong peak at approximately 470 ℃, implying that the interaction induces the generation of the strong acidic sites. As for the CO2-TPD curve (Fig. 5b), there is no peak for MgSO4 and ZrO2, indicating the absence of basicity sites. In contrast, MgSO4/ZrO2 has a peak around 310 ℃, indicating that MgSO4/ZrO2 produces basicity sites. These indicate that MgSO4/ZrO2 possesses stronger acid and base than MgSO4 and ZrO2. In addition, pyridine adsorption infrared spectroscopy is conducted to further analyze the nature of acidic groups in the catalysts. As shown in Fig. 5c, the absorption peak at 1450 cm−1 is attributed to Lewis acid site (L)[43] and the peak at 1540 cm−1 belongs to the Brønsted acid site (B). The peaks at 1489 cm−1 and 1609 cm−1 are Lewis and Brønsted acid sites (L + B)[44,45]. The amount of Lewis acid in MgSO4/ZrO2 is 6693.1 μmol/g while the amount of Bronsted acid is 19.2 μmol/g, indicating that the main acid sites in MgSO4/ZrO2 is the Lewis acid. 3.3 Adsorption/reaction heat for the catalyst To further investigate the effect of ZrO2 and MgSO4 in the MgSO4/ZrO2, the adsorption/reaction heat of different catalysts in different substrate solutions are measured with the microcalorimeter. As shown in Table 3 , the reaction heat of benzaldehyde (BAD) and TMSCF3 in DMF (the concentration is identical to the reaction concentration) on ZrO2 is 17.61 J·g−1 (Table 3, entry 1), which is an endothermic process. The reaction heat over MgSO4 is −534.86 J·g−1 (Table 3, entry 2), which is an exothermic process. As for the MgSO4/ZrO2, the reaction is an exothermic process whose heat is −368.71 J·g−1 (Table 3, entry 3). This indicates that MgSO4 plays the main role for the reaction catalysis over the MgSO4/ZrO2. To determine which substrates of the reactant mainly interact with the MgSO4/ZrO2 catalyst, the adsorption of TMSCF3 in DMF solution and BAD in DMF solution over the MgSO4/ZrO2 catalyst are conducted (Table 3, entries 4 and 5), respectively. The adsorption of TMSCF3 over the MgSO4/ZrO2 is an exothermic process whose adsorption heat is −1117.07 J·g−1 while the adsorption of BAD over the MgSO4/ZrO2 is an endothermic process with the heat of 29.55 J·g−1. This implies that TMSCF3 reactant has a stronger interaction over the MgSO4/ZrO2 than that of BAD reactant. Based above, it can be concluded that under the standard reaction condition TMSCF3 is mainly adsorbed among the two reactants and TMSCF3 mainly interacts with the surface MgSO4 sites of the MgSO4/ZrO2 catalyst. Besides, the adsorption heat of TMSCF3 and BAD over pristine MgSO4 is measured as 31.69 and 43.18 J·g−1, respectively. Compared with their adsorption over MgSO4/ZrO2 catalyst, the adsorption of TMSCF3 turns from endothermic adsorption (31.69 J·g−1) over MgSO4 to the greatly exothermic adsorption (−1117.07 J·g−1) over MgSO4/ZrO2. This indicates that the adsorption of TMSCF3 over MgSO4 sites is greatly enhanced when the MgSO4 is supported on ZrO2 due to the interaction between the MgSO4 and ZrO2 and the enhanced acid of MgSO4/ZrO2. 3.4 Reaction kinetic and catalytic mechanism To further investigate the reaction, the reaction kinetic was studied. The reaction order for benzaldehyde and TMSCF3 was determined according the kinetic curves. As shown in Fig. 6 , a good linear relationship can be obtained by plotting -ln(1-X) against the reaction time for both benzaldehyde and TMSCF3, indicating that the reaction is a first-order reaction for both benzaldehyde and TMSCF3 and the total reaction is a secondary reaction. This indicated that both benzaldehyde and TMSCF3 are involved in the intermediate during the reaction mechanism. Based on that the titled reaction is a typical nucleophilic reaction, the reaction can be recognized as the bimolecular nucleophilic substitution (SN2) reaction. Based on above characterizations of catalyst, the reaction/adsorption heat of the substrates over the catalyst, and literatures [3,14,22,46], the reaction mechanism is proposed as Scheme 1 . With the MgSO4 supported on the catalyst, the Lewis acid sites can be introduced in the catalyst (Scheme 1a). The oxygen atom from the sulfate over the surface of the catalyst as the Lewis base interacts with TMSCF3 to form a pentacore organosilicon intermediate over the surface of the catalyst (Scheme 1b). Next, the nucleophilicity of CF3 group is enhanced by the electron donated from Si atoms. The CF3 can react with the carbonyl group which is adsorbed on the Lewis sites of the catalyst to generate the alkoxy anion and trimethyl silicon cation ion pair intermediates on the surface (Scheme 1c). Subsequently, the O-silyl ether is released with the regeneration of the catalyst. Finally, the intermediate of silyl ether can be easily desilylated under acidic environment to produce trifluoromethylated alcohols. 3.5 Stability of the catalyst The filtration experiment is employed to examine whether the reaction is a truly heterogeneous catalysis process. As shown in Fig. 7a , the heterogeneous catalyst was removed at the reaction of 1 h. Subsequently, the reaction was conducted under the identical standard reaction condition. It can be found that the reaction completely stopped for the next following 1 h, which implies that the reaction is occurred under the truly heterogeneous way. Besides, the stability of the catalyst was tested. Fig. 7b shows that the catalytic performance is kept unchanged after 5 cycles, indicating that the catalyst possesses good stability. Moreover, the used catalyst was characterized by the FT-IR, Raman, XPS, and XRD technics to reveal the structure of used catalyst (Fig. S3-S5). It can be observed that there is no difference in the characterizations between the fresh and used catalyst, indicating that the catalyst has stable structure for the titled reaction. 3.6 Substrate scope Owing to the excellent catalytic performance for the trifluoromethylation of benzaldehyde with TMSCF3 over MgSO4/ZrO2, substituted benzaldehyde derivatives are employed to examine the universality of the present heterogeneous catalytic system. It can be found that the good yield of the trifluoromethylation products can be achieved with the electron-donating and electron-withdrawing groups on the benzaldehyde substrates. The yield is relatively low (60 %) when the substitute is the tert‑butyl group, which is due to the steric hindrance effect. It is worth note that the yield is still excellent when the substrate is terephthaldehyde and 4-pyridinecarboxaldehyde (Table 4 , entries 12–13). 4 Conclusion Heterogeneous catalyst of MgSO4/ZrO2 was explored for the trifluoromethylation of benzaldehyde with TMSCF3. It is revealed that the interactions between the MgSO4 and ZrO2 enhances the acidity and basicity of MgSO4/ZrO2. The main active sites for the reaction are the MgSO4 in the MgSO4/ZrO2. The enhanced Lewis acid and Lewis basic can significantly enhance the activity. The present catalyst possesses good stability without structure change of the catalyst during the reaction. Moreover, the present catalytic system shows good universality for trifluoromethylation of various benzaldehyde derivatives to the corresponding α-trifluoromethylbenzy alcohols. This work provides a potential route for designing the heterogeneous catalyst for the trifluoromethylation reaction. Notes The authors declare no competing financial interest. coredata.dc:description: Trifluoromethylation is an important route to achieve the organic fluorinated compounds. In the present work, heterogeneous catalyst of MgSO4/ZrO2 with Lewis base and acid was designed and prepared for the heterogeneous catalytic trifluoromethylation of aldehydes with (trifluoromethyl)trimethylsilane to the α-(trifluoromethyl)benzyl alcohol. The prepared catalyst was characterized to reveal its structure by XRD, FT-IR, Py-FTIR, Raman, XPS, NH3-TPD, CO2-TPD, and TGA. The heterogenous catalyst showed good catalytic performances with 99 % yield of α-(trifluoromethyl) benzyl alcohol at room temperature. The active sites on the surface of MgSO4/ZrO2 were investigated by the adsorption/reaction heat with the microcalorimeter. The reaction mechanism was proposed. The heterogenous catalyst possessed good stability for the entitled reaction. In addition, it showed good universality for the trifluoromethylation of various benzaldehyde derivatives to the corresponding α-(trifluoromethyl) benzyl alcohol.
coredata.dc:title: Efficiently nucleophilic trifluoromethylation of aldehydes over MgSO4/ZrO2 catalyst
